title: Projects
text: Planning and organizing events is often a tedious task as it requires multiple users and navigation of various websites. Event planning becomes even harder in the university setting as there are various groups and organizations that have to go through several departments to receive approvals for execution. I built an SQL based database system to introduce a convenient system for users to plan events, manage expenses, budgets, and many other crucial aspects of event organization.

title: Projects
section: Exploration of Spatially Specific Mentions in Narrative Text for Spatial Video Geonarratives
text:
Exploration of Spatially Specific Mentions in Narrative Text for Spatial Video Geonarratives
Through this project, I aimed to capture spatially specific mentions and comments related to needle use or drug-related objects by tracking investigators or participants as they identify or point to such items. This approach is based on research utilizing Spatial Video Geonarratives (SVG), a methodology in nursing research that leverages wearable cameras and GPS technology. SVG allows for the detailed study of needle debris in the environment, particularly in the context of homelessness and drug use, helping to inform public health strategies aimed at addressing these issues.

Welcome to my Website!
I am Vedasree Machiraju, a master’s student in Biomedical and Health Informatics at Case Western Reserve University’s School of Medicine, Department of Population and Quantitative Health Sciences. I hold a bachelor’s degree in Biology with a minor in Psychology from George Mason University. Along with my academic background, I bring practical experience from working in healthcare and currently serve as an intern at Wave Strategy.

title: Citation
text:
Konagalla, S., Azeem, M., Kumaravel, V., Machiraju, V., Nguyen, M., Decker, R.A., Pasham, S., Doma, S., Pendyala, R., Shanmugam, V., Waggel, S. The Psychological Impact on Healthcare Workers During the COVID-19 Pandemic. Manuscript under Review.
I am a co-author on a manuscript currently under review, which I contributed to during my internship with Dr. Stephanie Waggel, a psychiatrist. The study examines the effects of COVID-19 and its surrounding circumstances on healthcare workers.
